content: The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002, also known as the National Dam Safety Program Act, amends provisions related to the Interagency Committee on Dam Safety by focusing on coordination and information exchange among Federal agencies for implementing dam safety guidelines. The National Dam Safety Program, established by the Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002, focuses on coordination and information exchange among Federal agencies for implementing dam safety guidelines. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 amends various sections to improve dam safety in the United States. The Director is required to prepare a strategic plan with goals and cooperation with governmental entities in all states. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 aims to improve dam safety in the United States by establishing cooperation with governmental entities in all states, developing technical assistance materials, seminars, and guidelines, and coordinating national efforts to enhance dam safety. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 aims to improve dam safety in the United States by coordinating national efforts to enhance dam safety through the chairing of the Board. Amendments are made to sections regarding implementation plans, dam safety training, and assistance for state dam safety programs. Amendments are made to sections regarding assistance for state dam safety programs, specifying criteria for providing assistance to states in establishing, maintaining, and improving dam safety programs. The Board promotes coordination among Federal and State dam safety agencies to ensure the protection of human life and property in the United States. Work groups may be established to assist in achieving the Board's goals. The Director may establish work groups under the Board to assist in achieving its goals. Work groups consist of Board members and other selected individuals. Travel expenses for Board members representing Federal agencies are reimbursed by their respective agencies. Each member of the Board representing a Federal agency will be reimbursed for travel expenses, including per diem, while performing services for the Board. Members representing State agencies, the private sector, and work groups will be reimbursed by FEMA for their travel expenses. Each member of the Board, including those representing a State agency, the private sector, and work groups, will be reimbursed for travel expenses by FEMA at authorized rates while away from home or regular place of business. SEC. 4. RESEARCH. Amends Section 9(a) to cooperate with the Board, develop and support information resources systems for dam safety, and guide public policy for dam safety engineering. Adds initiatives for improving dam safety. SEC. 5. DAM SAFETY TRAINING. Amends the Act to provide training for State dam safety staff and inspectors upon request. SEC. 6. REPORTS. Amends Section 11 by removing subsection (a) and following text. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 13 of the Act is amended to increase annual amounts to $6,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. Allocation changes include updating references and removing specific assistance criteria. Research, dam safety training, and staff provisions are also revised. Section 13 of the Act is amended to increase annual amounts for research, dam safety training, and staff provisions. $1,500,000 is authorized for research, $500,000 for dam safety training, and $600,000 for staff employment for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2006.
